title: What percentage of U.S. equity funds will be outperformed by the S&P Composite 1500 index for the one-year period ending 30 June 2017?
preds:
not sure how to quantify this question without assuming practically all numbers. I like this analysis https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/515225 and also comments (and research) saying that analyst/HF managers greatly under-perform. I think five years is too small a window to judge (are  years 1 and 5 outliers or part of a pattern)
HF managers now know they under-perform so if they were to start being better then less fund should do worse (and high-frequency trading spreads have become very thin in last few years, and algos seem to change based on fund marketing profile rather than actively seeking and finding arbitrage possibilities.) I'm looking to the business cycle https://marketrealist.imgix.net/uploads/2016/04/BusineseCycle_Chart.jpg?w=660&fit=max&auto=format: 
Are we in a period of economic expansion that's peaking which roughly equates to late bull/early bear market? If so, growth in equities is iffy at best. S&P growth around 15.6% std and no signs of slowing. So equity funds that follow passive investing mantra and hug the index would do well in a choppy economic enviro. However, funds are victims of marketing and marketing works on differentiation - taking an easy way of making money and overly complicating it to stand out - the unintended consequence of which is that most managed funds should do poorly.
Upping categories 3 and 4 based on index performance.
I think that fund managers are hedging  more then individual investors but unless stock market tanks passive investment still works.

Lowered 3rd category 10% and raised 4th 10%. It's been researched heavily and as  pointed out above 90% of managers under perform. That said index and passive investing are overdone according to many and given the increase of bearish analysis about current market values I give a slightly higher odds of beating the S&P 1500.

Allocating non-zero amount to "less than 50%" after reading this article stating that 50% of mutual funds are outperforming because they are all piling into FANG's.  I don't have the original data and am not sure exactly how mutual fund performance is correlated with "US Equity Funds", but it is bullish information that I think is worth considering. https://hedgeaccordingly.com/2017/05/hedge-funds-outperform-benchmarks-thanks-to-massive-allocation-to-fang-fb-aapl-nflx-goog.html

The third week of May saw investors redeem money from U.S. Equity Funds for the seventh time in the past nine weeks as the political fallout from Trump’s abrupt firing of FBI Director continues to build.
Based on year end summary at http://us.spindices.com/documents/spiva/spiva-us-year-end-2016.pdf?force_download=true (quoted by Foghorn) and index performance up to now.

Seeing more and more irrationality of stock market so I am lowering 2nd category to 0, 2nd down to 25% from 40%, and raising to 75% from 60% 4th category. Irrational market and emotional investors make it difficult to outperform the market.
Historical data shows one in ten funds outperform each year, but that is only the average. Volatility could impact year-end results, making performance vs. benchmark random at arbitrary cutoff.

The end year (April 2017) data implies 60.49% over the past 1 year, compared to 90.20% in the 1 year before the September 2016 mid year. That's a huge fall away from previous marks. S&P index seems to have jumped a lot in the past year compared to the two years previous, which has perhaps helped make fund managers look good?
Past trends compared to how early into the new administration we are.
Increasing odds on top 2 categories. I'm seeing a lot of research that shows hedge fund managers rarely outperform the market consistently.
Prior 6/16 by H2 16 strong for small cap etc and looks to be coming through in spiva numbers too
Indexing King at moment, market dictates this be so...

As the US equity funds hold some small cap and foreign stocks their relative performance vs S&P1500 will depend in part on the relative performance of small cap and foreign stocks vs S&P1500 (as noted by Jeremy Grantham at GMO).  So recent small cap out performance (foreign stocks in line) should lower the typical percentage of underperformers.
Current macro environment is particularly hard for stock pickers leading to hardly beatable indexes

Decent chance of mid caps outperforming large cap, which would help active managers relative to the index (relative to other time periods). But fee drag is likely to mean most act managers will underperform.

As more and more money has moved to passive investing funds/ETF/Index funds, more an more is done by automated trading and everyone is choosing the same stocks.  In a dialectic way, this may lead to a countertrend in which the relative performance of stockpickers improves.
Mishandling of economy by Trump administration is under valued.
A lot of years have fallen close to fifty percent. If overall market is strong underperformance seems to be higher.

As explained in https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/465228, I use the average of the last 8 years and correct it for a trend of approx. 2% p.a. In the previous estimate, I only used half-year data as I saw a data quality issue between half-year data and full-year data.
I have updated my data with the recently released full-year data for 2016. The difference between half-year and full-year diminishes but is still there.
Seeing that the consensus so strongly favors the 70-90% range, I will cut down my exposure by using the average of half-year and full-year data.

The last 16 years of SPIVA data on this question have a mean of 58.75% and follow this probability distribution:
38%  Less than 50%
46%  Between 50% and 70%, inclusive
16%  More than 70% but less than 90%
  0%  90% or more With the 2016 calendar year number coming in at 60.49%, this looks like a typical year, with the best-guess point estimate of 60%.  I adjust the probability distribution above to give extra weight to the "Between 50% and 70%, inclusive" answer because of the "sneak peak" provided by last week's data.

Last week's release of  the 2016 year-end report showed that the percentage was reported to be 60.49%, down from 74.03% for the year before.  This implies that for the last 6 months of 2016 (which would be the first 6 months of the period in the question), the percentage of funds outperformed by the S&P 1500 Index was is in the vicinity of 60%.  70% or higher seems unlikely with the revelation of the new data.
Down from 25% to 20% in between 50 and 70% up to 35% from 30% in 90% or more.

I've only been able to find 1 conclusive report of US equity funds vs S&P1500, which concluded that around 75.2% of funds were beaten between 2008-2013 on average.
However, I hope to revise my forecast whenever I can get my hands on more data.
Any links to reports on this topic would be greatly appreciated!

The index currently performed about 15% for the last year. In addition, it seems like a majority of the managers usually get beaten by the market. Also, the S&P 500 is up about 15% as well, only slightly less than the S&P 1500. So it doesn't seem managers following that index will easily beat this composite.

Looking over past reports, 90.02 seems like an anomaly. In the two prior reports, year-end 2015 and mid-year 2015, the numbers were 74.81 & 63.57 respectively. While I think the uncertainty of the global political environment will keep this percentage elevated but I doubt it will remain over 90%.
On average these funds underperform simply because of administrative costs. The only significant advantage of equity funds, based upon historical data, is risk avoidance.

1 year base rate is probably closer to 87% than 90% as 10 year % from June 2016 was 87.47%; I'd adjust the midpoint of my expectation to 82.5-85% for now as I'd expect a reversal of such widespread under performance with a flatter market in 2017 (forward P/E is at 50 year highs ex tech bubble with significant growth priced in.)  Probability curve is not symmetric but if midpoint is around 84%, then a result between -14% and +6% of the midpoint is much more likely than more than +6%  midpoint (90% or above) or below -14% midpoint (50-70%).

If things keep going the way they are, you would expect similar performance to years past. With the rise in passive investing however, you have to wonder if only the mutual funds that outperform their benchmark will manage to stay around.

For the last decade S&P has been outperforming equity funds more than 9 out 10 times. That alone makes me put lots of weight in favour of S&P. I also expect tremendous amont of global capital being poured in to the US equities mainly from EU pushing the US markets up like crazy. We know that S&P underperformes in "good" times and that makes me adjust my expectations down a notch. Let's see what will weigh on more heavily.
If the stock market tanks, the number of funds underperforming the index could increase. But perhaps more likely to fall back within historical ranges.

In general, the SPIVA and Economist (Morningstar) data are reasonably close (except 2003). I've used the SPIVA numbers and added the earlier years from the Economist article giving 21 years in total. Distribution is:
<50%: 6 years, 29%
50-70%: 9 years, 43%
70-90%: 5 years, 24%
>90%: 1 year, 5% The average is around 63%. These figures seem reasonable as a base case. However, I think the fund split also needs to be taken into account. Typically, a higher proportion of funds outperform the index when small caps outperform large caps (although I have not actually confirmed this is the case). This seems reasonable as the Composite S&P1500 is dominated by the large-cap S&P500. The S&P1500 has returned +13.8% since 30 June 2016, while the S&P500 is +13.5%,  the Mid Cap S&P400 is +15.5% and Small Cap S&P600 is +19.2%. Therefore, assuming no change before mid-year, a higher proportion of the Large cap funds should underperform, while more mid-cap funds should outperform and most of the small cap funds should outperform. SPIVA gives the fund split of fund in the mid-year report which I assume hasn't changed: 24% of funds are multi-cap, 38% large-cap, 14% mid-cap and 24% small-cap. I assume the S&P1500 outperforms 60% of multi-cap, 70% of large-cap, 40% of mid-cap and 20% of small-cap (these figures are arbitrary guesstimates). Overall, therefore, the index should outperform roughly 51% of the funds (24%*60%+38%*70%+14%*40%+24%*20%). The 8% for 70-90% is also a guesstimate. A more accurate method would probably be to regress the performance of the constituent indices against the overall figure. Alternatively, it may be possible to get data on all the funds and sort their relative performance as of today, although I couldn't find a website which allows you to set a specific starting date (I think Morningstar enables ranking over -1 year).
This is no longer in doubt: index trackers win.

It does seem to be a narrowing range of outperformance by the index based on cost of money, as index  represents a strong part of the economy that benefits from cheap money, I am betting in the incompetence of allocators and funds managers reliance in quant data to outperform the index. So far the only ones that we know that can outperform the indexes year in year out,  are those who buy inside information in short term trades or run a strong front running operation, the rest fall in the lucky charm category.
Now, that it is only a dispersion of values (not atmospheric or personal views!!!!), if the past correlations stay in the same range (this is not a three sigma range for short term) and follow the same pattern, we are set to be more in tune with the 90% than with the 70%-90% by decimals, thus a narrow early forecast.

I compiled the available data:
- year-end for the last 15 years (2000-2015)
- mid-year for the last 9 years (2008-2016)
and analyzed it. The sample sizes are very small of course and one needs to be careful not to draw too many conclusions. Interestingly, I see two phenomena:
1) There seems to be a trend toward a higher share of underperforming funds over time. This trend even holds up when only looking at the last 8 years for which we have comparable mid-year and full-year data. I assume that there may be either a market/technology development or higher transparency behind it, but am not sure.
2) The mid-year numbers vary quite strongly from the full-year numbers, with higher 50-70% at mid-year which migrates to 70-90% at year-end. Again, this may be linked to transparency? As a result, I think that one should:
- use the average over the last 8 years (rather than the last 15 years)
- one should rather use the mid-year numbers than the year-end numbers
- one should factor in 2-3% increase of the average per year
But again, all of the above relying on a small sample size, one should not put too much faith in its statistical analysis in my view. Also interestingly, the mean & median over 15 years are approx. 60%, not 75% as indicated by the SPIVA in the article I mentioned in an earlier post. But the median comes close to 75% once one corrects for the trend. Thanks a lot to @Dsarin, @alanne, @KaizenCFALA for the links!

Initial forecast. Thanks to @alanne  and @KaizenCFALA for the links. I see lots of big reversion towards the mean following the worst years. This all but takes the 90% bucket out of the equation for me.

For all you fund managers out there, some simple ideas implementing mean reversion to outperform the indexes
https://www.quantopian.com/posts/enhancing-short-term-mean-reversion-strategies-1

Mid year reports from the kind link in the question:
2017: ??, S&P up 13.7% over trailing 1 year thus far
2016: 90.2% performed worse than S&P 1500, S&P 500 up 3.99% over trailing 1 year
2015: 63.7% performed worse than S&P 1500, S&P 500 up 7.42% over trailing 1 year
2014: 60.2% performed worse than S&P 1500, S&P 500 up 24.6% over trailing 1 year
2013: 54.28% performed worse than S&P 1500, S&P 500 up 20.6% over trailing 1 year
2012: 89.84% performed worse than S&P 1500, S&P 500 up 3.14% over trailing 1 year None of the last 5 years < 50%. => 0%
3/5 last five years between 50 and 70 => 60%
1/5 last five years between 70 and 90 => 20%
barely 1 year over 90% => 0% It looks like rough correlation between S&P returns and how well funds do, so I bump 50-70 by 10%.

Aye Soe, Senior Director at S&P, writes that "based on our 15 years of publishing the SPIVA U.S. Scorecard, we know that, on average, around 20% to 30% of domestic equity managers successfully outperform the benchmark in any given year" but does not give detailed data for the previous years and we cannot calculate statistics.
75% is pretty far away from 90.2%, though, and I will assume that 2016 was an exception. I'll shoot from the hip a 90:10.
https://www.indexologyblog.com/2017/03/07/manager-outperformance-is-it-luck-or-skill/

The mid year 2016 number of 90.2% of U.S. equity funds being outperformed by the index appears to a rare case.  Here, The Economist magazine lists 20 recent calendar years, none of which show more than 90% being outperformed:  http://www.economist.com/blogs/buttonwood/2015/02/mutual-fund-investing
My probability distribution is based on the 20-year sample in the article plus the solitary year of mid-2016 in the SPIVA report, so a sample size of 21.
Checked a couple of summaries and bet the trend

Below 70% can safely be at zero as there is no history of it. Looking at the one year 90.2%, the three year 87.41 and the five year at 94.58 means it is a tight call between over or under 90. If anyone has a good handle on what could influence that one way or the other I would love to know.
Buffet and I are in raging agreement on the goodness of index funds. But I wouldn't invest in a USA/EU based index fund, which have yielded poor returns and are subject to financial crisis risk.
Last year was an outlier; the base rate is much lower.
